long_desc.thetext: Thanks - I'll take a look at it.

From the IRC channel:
<suiryc> happens that current code asks to the network API what to handle, and it gets one hint for IPv4 abd another for IPv6 <suiryc> so the master actually starts two service instances, one dedicated to IPv4 and a separate one for IPv6

I was poking about in the master code for unrelated reasons, and I thought I spotted a couple of places where the accounting for the number of worker processes in READY state can get confused and underestimate. This would result in too many workers being preforked. However, both of those would require going through UNKNOWN state, which Shouldn't Happen (tm) so I'm not concerned.
But as Bron points out, the way the Cyrus master process handles a 'listen' parameter which translates to multiple addresses (i.e. IPv4 and IPv6), means that the effect of the 'prefork', 'maxchild' and 'maxforkrate' parameters are applied to the (service,address) tuple and not the service itself. This is unintuitive and unclear in the documentation but probably not broken.
I think the best thing to do is to document the behaviour in the cyrus.conf(5) manpage. Also, the maxforkrate parameter is not documented.
Ok - I've documented the behaviour. W00t.
